text: Well, Sandra, President Trump is now giving a dire warning to Iranian leadership, writing on Truth Social this morning that a massive armada is heading
towards Iran and is ready to quote, "Fulfill its mission with speed and violence if necessary." Chief national security correspondent Jennifer Griffin
is tracking the latest for us on this.
And Jennifer, it sounds like Iranian leaders are now responding with their own warning. What can you tell us?
That's right, Bill. In fact, the rhetoric is getting increasingly heated from the leaders in Iran. We have a statement from one of those leaders in
which he said that any US strike would be met with an immediate response unprecedented. He described uh we also heard from Iran's foreign minister uh
that that the armed forces in Iran have their fingers on the trigger and the Ayatollah Ali himself said that any illusion that the US any US strikes
would be limited is an illusion at that.
The president however is deploying a clear carrot and stick strategy toward Iran. The USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft
carrier strike group is now in sinkcom control with its three guided missile destroyers and dozens of combat aircraft
including stealth F35 fighter jets and FA18 fighter jets and literally hundreds of Tomahawk cruise missiles capable of
reaching Iranian targets. President Trump also offering an olive branch.
There's another beautiful armada floating beautifully toward Iran right now. So, we'll see.
I hope I hope they make a deal. I hope they make a deal. They should have made a deal the first time to have a country.
The protests may have ebbed, but they will spark up again in the future because this regime, unless they are willing to change and/or leave, have no
way of addressing the legitimate and consistent complaints of the people of Iran who deserve better.
The US Air Force is running regional military exercises this week to signal readiness. Officials see a real chance
President Trump acts, but an equal chance Iran blinks. He's setting the theater in a way that gives him lots of options in the near term and probably
even for a little bit of a a longer runway looking out into the future. So if tomorrow or a week from now or a month from now there were a strike on
Iran by the United States or in concert with others, I wouldn't be a bit surprised. I think if you are the Ayatollah
and you look at the military buildup in the region, he has to wonder whether he will suffer the same fate as Madura or
something worse if he doesn't come to the negotiating table. Iran's ambassador to the UN responded. Last time the US
blundered into wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, it squandered over 7 trillion dollars and lost more than 7,000 American lives. Iran stands ready for
dialogue based on mutual respect and interests, but if pushed, it will defend itself and respond like never before.
Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, Bill, said publicly it would not let anyone use its bases to attack Iran. Bill?
Yeah. At this point, Iran has to know the president is not bluffing. Jennifer Griffin live here in Washington. Jen, thank you.
I'm Steve Ducey. I'm Brian Kilme.
And I'm Anley Airheart. And click here to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube page to catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis.
